repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Profile startup time until neovim starts listening for user input. This includes some of the first processed events.

One caveat with this is that startup time profiling plugins won't have any reliable way of knowing when to close neovim after running it with `--startuptime`. I think this could be solved by adding a new event, like maybe `ProfileDone`, `ProfileWritten`, `VimReady`?

comment_data.body:
`v:vim_did_enter` is set before `VimEnter` event, so everything from `VimEnter autocommands` can still be cut short if something like `prompt()` is called inside a `VimEnter` autocommand.

The alternative is to create a boolean flag and set it where `first screen update` is printed, and then check it here.

why do we need both messages? `--- NVIM STARTED ---` has been redefined to mean "ready for user input" in this PR. So we don't need the "ready for user input" message?

Probably need a doc update at `:help --startuptime`.

follow existing conventions

```suggestion
extern bool did_first_redraw;
```

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -110,7 +110,10 @@ argument.
 		This can be used to find out where time is spent while loading
 		your |config|, plugins and opening the first file.
 		When {fname} already exists new messages are appended.
-
+		If your profiler script needs to know when to quit, use:
+>
+		nvim --startuptime nvim.log +'set ut=0 | au CursorHold * qa!'

comment_data.body: `vim.schedule(function() vim.cmd('qa!') end)`? Doesn't work, it's executed before reaching `os_inchar`

+>

comment_data.body: What? I mean `vim.schedule(function() vim.o.updatetime = 1000 end)`, then there will be a delay before `CursorHold`.

comment_data.body: I don't really understand what would be the point of that. My intention behind `:set ut=0` was to make `CursorHold` trigger as soon as possible, and therefore quit neovim as soon as possible.

comment_data.body: So it doesn't work if someone has this kind of thing in their config.

comment_data.body:
So to be clear, by "doesn't work" I mean that neovim quits before `--- NVIM IDLE ---` message.

IIRC `+`/`-c` commands are executed after the config, so I believe this should overwrite it. In worst case scenario if the user still manages to change `'updatetime'` to a higher value from the config, it will just take a little bit longer for neovim to quit.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -110,7 +110,10 @@ argument.
 		This can be used to find out where time is spent while loading
 		your |config|, plugins and opening the first file.
 		When {fname} already exists new messages are appended.
-
+		If your profiler script needs to know when to quit, use:
+>
+		nvim --startuptime nvim.log +'set ut=0 | au CursorHold * qa!'

comment_regular_data.body:
> One caveat with this is that startup time profiling plugins won't have any reliable way of knowing when to close neovim after running it with `--startuptime`. I think this could be solved by adding a new event, like maybe `ProfileDone`, `ProfileWritten`, `VimReady`?

? Is that because they were checking for `--- NVIM STARTED ---` ? Why is it important for them to "know when to close"? Can they do `-c 'call nvim_input('qa!<cr>')` or something?

Profiling plugins run neovim with `--startuptime` few times and then take the average, they need to quit neovim after the log file was generated. I think just `+q` from the command line used to work in the past, but that was broken at some point and I think plugins now use a 0ms timer to run `:q` or something like that.

I tried `nvim_input` and it doesn't work

> I tried `nvim_input` and it doesn't work

I assume "doesn't work" means it quits too soon? I wonder if `getchar(1)` might work (i.e. does it wait until input is ready to be accepted, before returning?)

> `v:vim_did_enter` is set before `VimEnter` event, so everything from `VimEnter autocommands` can still be cut short if something like `prompt()` is called inside a `VimEnter` autocommand.

This seems circular. We've are saying "ready for input" is when Nvim has started. But `nvim_input("qa!")` quits too soon? That seems contradictory.
Yes, it quits too soon. "Ready for user input" might not be the best way to describe it, it's when neovim first enters the "idle state".

> it's when neovim first enters the "idle state".

This seems very fragile, as we've already discovered. Which will be really confusing for people writing profiling scripts, not to mention people just running `nvim --startuptime` that happen to maybe hit a key during startup?

What is the goal here?

When you hit a key during startup, it will just be included in the profiling. This is already how it works right now, you can put `call getchar()` in init.vim and the time it took to hit a key will be counted in too. I don't think this is fragile, it was just badly described, as I believe the input is always buffered somewhere since the beginning, it just might be processed later.

The goal is more detailed startup logs, and including the processing of initial events in that.

> it's when neovim first enters the "idle state".

If it's idle then maybe firing `CursorHold` makes sense.  Probably shouldn't redefine `VimEnter`. Unsure about `VimReady`, this seems like such a special case.

Yup, `nvim --startuptime nvim.log +'set ut=0 | au CursorHold * q!'` works.

Alternatively, we could leave `--- NVIM STARTED ---` message where it is now, and add something like maybe `--- NVIM IDLE ---` after that? Doesn't require any changes in plugins, and parsing it would be optional.

> we could leave `--- NVIM STARTED ---` message where it is now, and add something like maybe `--- NVIM IDLE ---` after that? Doesn't require any changes in plugins, and parsing it would be optional.

No objection, but... profilers that want to measure time to "NVIM IDLE" still need a way to "know when to quit", right?

> `nvim --startuptime nvim.log +'set ut=0 | au CursorHold * q!'` works.

Oh cool, let's document that at `:help --startuptime` with an opening like "If your profiler script needs to know when to quit..."

The profilers that want to include the measurement will have to use `CursorHold`, and the profilers that don't will just do what they were already doing and quit earlier, before the NVIM IDLE message is appended to the file.
Is this done? Just squash and write a real commit message.
Is this still needed since the `SafeState` event was added? We could document that though.

The problem was that profiling ended early, while some plugin initialization could still be happening. So the actual problem was how to extend the profiler to cover that part too.

Personally, I'm fine with closing this though.
Let's close this until we have details about why `SafeState` isn't good enough.

title: feat(profile): add "NVIM IDLE" to --startuptime
